review.title: Exploiting Text and Network Context for Geolocation of Social Media Users
review.abstract: Research on automatically geolocating social media users has conventionally been based on the text content of posts from a given user or the social network of the user, with very little crossover between the two, and no bench-marking of the two approaches over compara- ble datasets. We bring the two threads of research together in first proposing a text-based method based on adaptive grids, followed by a hybrid network- and text-based method. Evaluating over three Twitter datasets, we show that the empirical difference between text- and network-based methods is not great, and that hybridisation of the two is superior to the component methods, especially in contexts where the user graph is not well connected. We achieve state-of-the-art results on all three datasets.

metadata.title: Exploiting Text and Network Context for Geolocation of Social Media Users

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Recently, interest in the task of deriving the location of users of social media services has skyrocketed due to their usefulness in applications such as location-based information retrieval (Amitay et al., 2004), recommendation systems (Noulas et al., 2012), and rapid disaster response methods (Earle et al., 2010). Social media sites such as Twitter and Facebook provide users with two primary means of indicating their location: (1) through text-based metadata fields in the user profile; and (2) through GPS-based geotagging of posts and checkins. However, text-based metadata is often lacking, misleading or inaccurate, and only a tiny percentage of users geotag their posts (Cheng et al., 2010). Given the low number of users with reliable location information, there is considerable interest in the task of automatic geolocation (predicting lat / long coordinates) of the users based on their location, the metadata available in their social media posts, and in their social networks.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Previous work on user geolocation can be broadly divided into two categories: text-based and network-based methods. Common to both methods is the way in which the problem of geolocation is formulated. Geographical coordinates have a real value and, accordingly, this is most naturally modelled as (multiple) regression. However, for convenience modelling, the problem is typically simplified to a classification by first dividing the regions into individual sub-regions, using either known city locations (Han et al., 2012; Rout et al., 2013) or k-d tree partitioning (Roller et al., 2012; Wing and Baldridge, 2014). In k-d tree methods, the resulting discrete regions are treated either as a flat list (as here) or as a nested hierarchy.

sections.heading: 2.1 Text-based Geolocation
sections.text: Text-based approaches assume that the language in social media is geographically distorted, which is clearly recognizable for regions that speak different languages (Han et al., 2014), but is also reflected in regional dialects and the use of region-specific terminology. Text-based models mainly use terms to learn regional classifiers (Roller et al., 2012; Wing and Baldridge, 2014), including the selection of characteristics for location-specific terms (Han et al., 2012). Topic models have also been used for the use of geospatial texts (Eisenstein et al., 2010; Ahmed et al., 2013) by linking latent topics to places, which has the advantage that predictions can be made over continuous space, i.e. without the problem having to be presented as classification. On the other hand, these methods exhibit high algorithmic complexity and their generative formulation is unlikely to compete with the performance of discriminatory methods on large data sets.

sections.heading: 2.2 Network-based Geolocation
sections.text: Although online social networking sites allow for global interaction, users tend to befriend and interact with many of the same people online as offline (Rout et al., 2013). Network-based methods use this feature to derive users "location from their friends" locations (Jurgens, 2013; Rout et al., 2013). A major caveat about the generality of these techniques is that friendship graphics are often inaccessible, for example by disseminating location information (Facebook) or hiding behind a highly frequency-restricted API (Twitter) (Jurgens, 2013; Talukdar and Crammer, 2009). A major caveat about the generality of these techniques is that friendship graphics are often not accessible, e.g. secured by the public (Facebook) or hidden behind a highly frequency-restricted API (Twitter).

sections.heading: 4.1 Text-based Classification
sections.text: Our basic method for text-based geolocation is based on Wing and Baldridge (2014), which formulate the geolocation problem as a classification using k-d trees. In summary, their approach initially discredits the continuous space of geographical coordinates using a k-d tree, so that each subregion (leaf) has similar user numbers. In many small regions for areas with high population density and less large regions for rural areas with low population density, this leads to a discreditation. Next, they use these regions as class labels to train a logistic regression model ("LR"). sections.heading: 4.2 Network-based Label Propagation
sections.text: Next, consider the approach of Jurgens (2013), which used label dissemination ("LP"; Zhu and Ghahramani (2002)) to derive user locations through social networking. Jurgens (2013) defined an undirected network of interactions between Twitter users based on @ mentions in their tweets, a mechanism typically used for conversations between friends. Consequently, these links often correspond to offline friendships, and accordingly, the network will have a high level of localization when each user mentions the other. The network is constructed by defining all users in a data set (train and test) as nodes, as well as other external users mentioned in their tweets. Unlike Jurgens (2013), which only generated edges when both users mentioned the other, we created edges when both users mentioned the other. For the three sets of data we used to be direct, which were used in our experiments, and therefore to be less-direct.

sections.heading: 4.3 A Hybrid Method
sections.text: Unfortunately, many test users are not transitively connected to any training node (see Table 1), which means that LP cannot assign a location to them. This can happen when users do not use @ mentions or when a group of nodes are a separate component of the chart. sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: The results are also linked to the state of the art.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We have a number of approaches to social media geolocation based on: (1) text-based analysis using logistic regression with regularization; (2) network-based analysis using label propagation; and (3) a hybrid method based on network-based label propagation and back-off to text-based analysis for unconnected users. We get state-of-the-art results from three existing Twitter records and find that the hybrid method is superior to the two component methods. The LP-LR method is a hybrid approach that uses the LR predictions as priors. It is not simply a backoff of network information to text-based information in the sense that it propagates the LR geolocation through the network. That's when a test node is separated from the training node but still has connections to other test nodes, the geolocation is adapted and propagated through the network.
